data.name: Shelve your trophies
data.description:
Being a very successful athlete, you have a bunch of trophies to put in your case (well done!); however, you're very particular about the organization of your trophies, so you give yourself a set of rules before you begin — but now you wonder, given a set of rules for your trophies, how many different ways can you shelve these trophies? 

There are three types of rules you put for yourself: 
1. Two trophies cannot be on the same shelf
2. Two trophies must be a distance n apart
3. A trophy cannot be on a certain shelf


Your method will be given 3 inputs:
1. shelves: an integer number of shelves
2. n_trophies: an integer number of trophies
3. rules: a list of rules

Where the rules are strings which will be formatted as such:

1. "t1.x.t2" means t1 cannot be on the same shelf as t2
2. "t1.n.t2" where n is any integer means t1 must be n shelves away from t2 (n will always be less than the number of shelves)
3. "t.#.s" means t cannot be on shelf s
  
For example, a method call might look like
```python
shelves = 3
n_trophies = 6
rules = ["3.x.5", "0.1.5", "4.#.2"]

n_shelves = shelve_trophies(shelves, n_trophies, rules) # should return 144
```
limits:
```
2 <= shelves <= 5
4 <= n_trophies <= 10 
len(rules) <= 7
```
One final note: the shelvings are unordered — i.e. it doesn't matter how all the trophies are arranged on each shelf, it only matters what shelves they're on. Good luck!
